what is an isotope?: A variant of an element with a different number of neutrons
what is a compound?: A molecule with two different elements
what is an element?: A substance with only one type of atom
which is a stable isotope?: An isotope with a stable nucleus
what makes a compound different from a m: Compounds have a fixed ratio of elements
how does salt dissolve in water?: Water molecules surround and isolate the ions
why does ice float on water?: Ice is less dense than water
how do fish survive in ponds that freeze: Live in the water below ice
how do bees survive during the winter?: They stay warm in the hive
what is the Glycemic Index (GI)?: A measure of how quickly food raises blood sugar
why is GI important for diabetes managem: It helps manage blood sugar levels
what is a characteristic of steroids?: They consist of four fused rings
dehydration synthesis involves the:: Removal of water to form bonds
what is the primary difference between s: Saturated fats are solid at room temperature, unsaturated fats are not
which of the following statements is tru: It releases water as a byproduct
what is the defining characteristic of a: It consists of two or more elements chemically combined in definite proportions.
which of the following is a key characte: They are unstable and release radiation as they break down.

which of the following is a primary char: They are all hydrophobic, meaning they do not mix with water.
what is the key chemical feature of a sa: It has no double bonds between the carbon atoms.
what does the Glycemic Index (GI) measur: How quickly a food containing carbohydrates raises blood sugar levels.
why is consuming low-GI foods beneficial: They are absorbed slowly, leading to a gradual rise in blood sugar levels.
how can a diet consisting of low-GI food: It may improve insulin sensitivity over time.
what is the primary reason that low-GI f: They help in avoiding sharp spikes and subsequent crashes in blood sugar levels.
when iodine solution is added to the pot: A positive test for the presence of starch.
what is the main function of cellulose i: It makes up the plant cell walls.
what are the final products of carbohydr: Monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, and fructose
what is the primary function of a buffer: To resist sharp, sudden changes in pH.
why is water referred to as the \"univer: It is a highly polar molecule, allowing it to dissolve all polar and ionic substances.
which of the following describes a suspe: A mixture of water and non-dissolved material.
in a water molecule (H2O), which of the: The hydrogen atom has a partial positive charge, and the oxygen atom has a partial negative charge.
which of the following best defines cohe: The attraction of molecules of the same substance.
in a water molecule (H2O), what are the: Hydrogen is partially positive, and oxygen is partially negative.
why is ice less dense than liquid water?: The hydrogen bonds in the ice's crystal lattice structure hold the molecules farther apart than in liquid water.
The water molecules in ice form a crystal lattice with more space between them.
water has a high heat capacity. This mea: It can absorb a large amount of heat with only a small change in temperature.
the 'beading' of water on a waxy surface: The cohesive forces of water are stronger than the adhesive forces between water and wax.
an atom's structure consists of specific: The nucleus has positive protons and neutral neutrons. Negative electrons orbit this central core.
two atoms of the same element have the s: They are called isotopes, atoms of the same element that differ only in their number of neutrons in the nucleus.
a chemical bond forms when one atom comp: An ionic bond, which results from the electrostatic attraction between positively and negatively charged ions.
the polarity of water molecules causes t: Hydrogen bond, a weak attraction between the slightly positive hydrogen of one molecule and the oxygen of another.
nonpolar substances like oil do not mix: Hydrophobic, a "water-hating" property of nonpolar substances that do not dissolve in water.

in the Cell theory, Matthias Schleiden c: all plants are made of cells
the cell theory states:: All living things are made up of cells; Cells are the basic units of structure and function in living things; New cells are produced from existing cells.
german physician rudolfvirchow published: new cells can be produced only from the division of existing cells.
in the cell theory theodor schwann state: all animals are made of cells.
what is the fundamental principle of dif: movement of particles from a high concentration area to a low concentration area
which of these is an everyday life examp: the smell of perfume spreading through a room
what is the biological example of diffus: oxygen moving from the lungs into the blood
why does exercise improve gas exchange: it maintains a steep diffusion gradient for o2 and co2
does the process of diffusion require th: no, it is a passive process
what is osmosis specifically defined as: the movement of water through a semipermeable membrane
what happens to cucumber slices placed i: they shrivel because water moves out of their cells
why does salting meat or fish act as a p: bacteria on the meat lose water by osmosis and die
why is it dangerous to drink seawater: it is hypertonic and will cause cells to lose water (dehydration)
why is pure water not injected into the: it is hypotonic, causing blood cells to swell and burst
what is the purpose of oral rehydration: to restore osmotic equilibrium after dehydration
does the process of osmosis require the: no, it is a passive process
how does diabetes connect to facilitated: without insulin, glucose cannot efficiently enter cells by facilitated diffusion
what is the defining feature of active t: it requires energy (atp) to move substances against their gradient
what biological example of active transp: the sodium-potassium pump in nerve cells
what is the function of the sodium potas: to maintain electrical balance for nerve function
why is a constant energy supply crucial: because active transport fails without energy
what happens to a cells life functions i: the cell can no longer maintain them
according to the text, what is the funda: They use beams of light or electrons to produce magnified images.
in a compound light microscope, what is: It enlarges the image of the specimen.
what is a primary limitation of light mi: They are limited to a magnification of about 1000 times.
why are chemical stains or dyes used wit: To make the nearly transparent cells visible.
what is a major disadvantage of using el: They can only be used to examine nonliving cells and tissues.
what is the defining characteristic that: Eukaryotes enclose their DNA in a nucleus, while prokaryotes do not.
what did robert hooke observe that led h: Tiny empty chambers in a slice of cork.
what did german botanist matthias schlei: All plants are made of cells.
in a prokaryotic cell, where is the gene: Freely within the cell, not enclosed in a nucleus
what does the text say about the cells o: They are specialized for specific tasks.
why must samples be placed in a vacuum f: Because electrons are easily scattered by molecules in the air.
how do prokaryotic cells compare to euka: They are generally smaller and simpler.
the term \"transmission\" in transmissio: a beam of electrons is sent through a thin sample.
what is one of the three main points of: Cells are the basic units of structure and function in living things.
what is the purpose of dna replication ?: Pass genetic information to new cells
what is a catalyst ?: A substance that speeds up a reaction
why are enzymes required for life ?: Many reactions are too slow without them
what are accessory pigments, like carote: Absorbing light in other regions of the spectrum
how does chlorophyll make photosynthesis: It transfers light energy to its own electrons
what is the overall process of photosynt: Using sunlight energy to convert water and CO2 into sugars and oxygen
plants use the sugars produced in photos: To produce complex carbohydrates like starches
what happens to the oxygen atoms from th: They are released to the atmosphere as oxygen gas
what is another name for the light-indep: The text does not provide one
how are the light-dependent and light-in: They are interdependent and work together
what is the ultimate purpose of the two: To capture sunlight energy and transform it into energy-rich compounds
what is the visible spectrum?: The wavelengths of light visible to our eyes
what is the primary purpose of the bmi c: To set a clear objective (e.g., weight loss, gain, maintenance)
what is a healthy, recommended calorie s: 300-500 calories per day more than TDEE
what challenge is common for individuals: The physical difficulty of eating enough calories
what is the importance of micronutrients: They do not provide energy/calories but act as catalysts for chemical processes
what is a calorie (lowercase c) defined: The energy needed to raise the temp of 1 gram of water 1 degree Celsius
the word equation for the overall proces: Oxygen + Glucose → Carbon dioxide + Water + Energy
what is the primary function of food for: To provide chemical building blocks and chemical energy
what molecules are used by the electron: High-energy electrons from glycolysis and the Krebs cycle
when a person is hungry and feels weak,: That your energy supplies are low
what is the fundamental nature of the ch: It is a catabolic process carried out anaerobically.
alcoholic fermentation is used in the pr: Beer, wine, and other alcoholic beverages.
besides producing alcoholic beverages, w: It causes the bread dough to rise.
how does lactic acid fermentation differ: LAF does not give off carbon dioxide, while AF does.
what is the role of lactic acid bacteria: To consume lactose and convert it into lactic acid.
under what condition do many human body: During brief periods without enough oxygen.
to keep going after the initial atp supp: Cellular respiration or lactic acid fermentation.
why do well-conditioned athletes have to: Because cellular respiration releases energy more slowly than fermentation.
